reviewText:
Burnout Paradise is an open world, survival horror game developed by Criterion Games, who are most known for making popular racing titles. The game is set in a horrific post-apocalyptic city, ironically called Paradise City. I can assure you however, there is no paradise to be seen in this hellish landscape.

You play as an unnamed, sentient car. The game revolves around completing the same missions over and over in order to upgrade your licence, to prove that you are king of the cars. The missions mostly involve destroying other cars, however, there are some racing elements involved here and there. As a working class peasant who cannot afford a luxury sports car, this appeals to my deep seated resentment of people who have more money than me.

[SPOILER ALERT] The story is fantastic. Towards the end of the game, you discover that you are not the protagionist at all. In fact, you are the villian. The real hero of the game is a DJ driven to madness named Atomica. Who has been broadcasting Paradise City's only radio station the entire game. His true motives are to get all of the cars in the city to destroy eachother, so that he can free humanity from its chains and rebuild society. Many games have tried to copy Burnout Paradise's clever plot twist, and have failed miserably. Ken Levine, eat your heart out. You can never hope to recreate this masterful storytelling.

In summary, Burnout Paradise is a masterpiece. There isn't a single game in existence that can match its artistic calibre. So I award this game ten out of ten cars. You will never get TYRED of this game.

(A lot of people are leaving comments pointing out the similarities to Yahtzees review. Fine, but Yahtzee wasn't the only person to think of this. This was meant to be a small joke amongst friends that just happened to get popular. Whining won't make me take it down.)

This game is seriously one of my favorite of all time. Yeah, just another EA racing game released in the 7th generation, but it's a very special EA racing game released in the 7th generation. CONS:

-Depending on the person, this will be a glaring flaw: the only real character, DJ Atomika, is a bit of a jerk.

Really good game. If you like racing games, it's a must have. 4/5

reviewText:
This is a great racing game that's all about driving in the open world of people-free Paradise City, of which the title song claims has green grass and pretty girls.  Along the way, you'll be bombarded with advertising billboards for such things like Burger King, EVGA motherboards, Crash FM, and this very game.  Sadly, you can only demolish one of these billboards, which keep reappearing continuously.  Somehow, I feel real sorry for the cleanup crews having to fix up the damage caused by driverless cars.  It's like Twilight Zone stuff, man!

While you repeat the events that you've already cleared with each new license, you get to hear a selection of licensed songs that usually repeat a pretty good deal.  Or you can listen to past Burnout songs from a time Acclaim published those games.  Maybe you just feel like listening to that Avril Lavinge song over and over.  Did you know that song was also in Burnout Dominator AND in multiple languages?  There are also classical songs in the game, but nobody listens to those. ;)

The damage model is quite glorious, parts flying off, cars flipping about, and [my favorite /s] the game going into super slow motion because you were too slow in reacting to a barrier right in front of you.  It's like you know you're going to be taunted mercilessly, especially if you crash mere seconds before the time trial expires.  But if you feel like crashing into things and causing mass destruction, there is a Showtime mode.  It's not quite like the crash modes in previous games, but it counts for something.

Even with the minor flaws like the lack of a certain bit of DLC that the potato consoles got to enjoy, super slow motion crashes that test your patience, and the general grind with each new license, this is still a very enjoyable racing game that people continue to play to this day.

reviewText:
A case of paradise found, or paradise lost?

I've played all Burnout games since Point of Impact, except Dominator. Paradise seemed just as exciting as previous titles in the series to begin with, but by the end it became an exercise in anger management. Having completed it on the PS3 I thought coming back to it on PC was going to be a cakewalk. If only.

Enjoying Paradise depends on a lot of ifs. Where you are at in the game, how much you intend to play, and how easily things annoy you, for starters.

The game dumps you on a map and basically says 'Enjoy!', leaving you to discover everything it offers for yourself. Perhaps the first and biggest wonder you'll notice is the miraculous lack of people - even the random cars you see on the road are all empty. Even your own car. Compared to games like GTA this is a bit of a sore point for me - having someone to run over and some voice-acting to laugh at would have been a nice addition. The only voice there is to listen to (besides the soundtrack / music) is DJ Atomica, who never ceases to bring you down with some disparaging remark when you lose an event. Sometimes he's ok, but the game would have been better off without his five pence of 'try harder' and 'the route you choose' bull.

If driving around in Robot City isn't a problem for you then you might like this title. There is a big garage of awesome looking cars to unlock, and the freedom of having a huge map fully unlocked already means you can pick and choose which roads to use in races and events. Occasionally it can get confusing, but the option is there to check an event's route before you start it, so you can take your time deciding how best to navigate the roads to get to where you need to as fast and effortlessly as possible.

Collectibles include challenges (both offline and online - online lists challenges for each of 2 players through to 8 players); smashes (which are construction fences that often fence off short-cuts); billboards (for smashing through as well); and super jumps. Just finding all of these can be a chore.

In addition, each road has a fastest lap record to beat, and a crash mode record to beat. Some roads are little, others are huge. Crash mode isn't quite the same as previous games though, where you get a specific set-up and have a bunch of buses all packed together in the distance. Instead, while driving you can start crash mode at the touch of a button (but careful not to start it in the middle of a race). The goal here is to rack up a big $$$ of carnage, hitting traffic, buses, signs, anything with a $$$ painted over it. The event stops when your boost bar empties, but is filled regularly as long as you keep hitting things. This is one of the more fun aspects of the game, but it can be frustrating too, as all too often the crash traffic will spawn on roads you can never possibly reach, sometimes you'll see traffic spawn in the distance only to de-spawn before it reaches you (possibly because too much traffic is spawning on other roads), and traffic has an awful habit of avoiding your bouncing wreck trying to aim for them. Overall it's fun, but I get the feeling it needs a patch or something.

Event types are colour-coded on the map, thankfully, as there are over a hundred and finding what you want can be problematic. They are broken down into races, burning routes (car-specific race against the clock), stunt runs, road rages (using your car to take out other cars within a time limit), and marked man (which is the biggest pile of doo-doo since Jurassic Park).

The goal of the game is to keep unlocking new licences, ending with the Burnout Elite licence, requiring you to complete everything. Up until this last licence it is possible to avoid most events you don't like, but this last licence forces you into events you may hate. For me it was Marked Man - an event that is akin to a bull in a china shop, with you playing as the china. It seems to me too heavily reliant on dumb luck just to survive the longer distances - repair drive-thrus often being too few or too far away to be of any use. I see it as utterly preposterous and totally unnecessary. Sometimes all you can do is sit and watch in sheer disbelief as attack cars rain down on your humble car from every possible angle, sometimes t-boning you mere seconds after respawning, leaving you no room to escape at all. And to top it all off DJ Atomica will whine at you afterwards, saying you have no skill.

Apologies to my brother, Grunner, and my family for all the foul language and violence when I started doing Marked Man.

It's a shame but I believe Marked Man events will be a game breaker for perfectionists looking to get 100%. It can be done, but you may find items around you will get broken in your rage. Lots of excessive cinematics in the menu and waiting for cars to drop in before you can choose them to drive make the game unnecessarily longer. The menu is messed up to begin with - you use F1 and F2 to navigate various menus and a web page - not to mention the fail webpage that still tries to load every time you start the game.

But the visuals are pretty good considering the game's age, and the soundtrack is pretty beast. If you're a racing fan, need more cars to play with and there's nothing better out there, then you'll get this despite the menu problems or stupid Marked Man. Due to all the enjoyment I've had I can't recommend against it, but it's pretty close. 50/50. Racing probably isn't for me.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Welcome to Paradise island, the island where you can run over almost everything, jump over everything else, and crash with little to no consequences. Burnout Paradise is an Open World racing game developed by Criterion Games and released in 2009.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: You start the game with a quick introduction to Paradise Island, after your introduction you try to accumulate â€œmarks on your licensesâ€ to progress to the next licenses and unlock new vehicles.
You earn Marks on your license by completing the various challenges, there is always a challenge at every intersection.... leaving you plenty of races, bumper cars, stunt drives, and chases to keep people entertained.
The primary vehicles you'll play as are Cars, but they do have some motorcycles in the game and some â€œtoy vehiclesâ€. In general this has a lot of vehicles which are very much wasted on me, because I just crash into the other vehicles because I'm childish and want to play bumper cars.

Gameplay: There are three car â€œclassesâ€, and different stats with each car. Stunt class cars will get you boosts by preforming tricks, Aggression class cars get you boosts by being a jerk (I really like playing Aggression cars and cackling evilly as I push an NPC into the wall), and lastly Speed class cars, which you fill by near misses, upon filling the boost you can preform â€œburnoutsâ€ which let you boost after your boost meter runs out, so in a way you could just keep boosting... as long as you don't crash in between boosts.
Like most car games, there are also specific stats on the various vehicles, some cars have high Speed, others have high boost, and still others have high Strength. Speed = you go faster. Boost = you have more boost you can charge up. Strength = your car can take a bigger beating from the competition.

Achievements: There are no steam achievements for this game, at this time. However there are plenty of in-game unlockables that you can obtain. It's important to note someday there might be steam achievements, because on the Xbox there are 60 achievements on the core game, + 10 with the various DLC expansions.

Price: Burnout Paradise is priced at $19.99, you can easily spend an hour for every dollar spent playing this game, there's a lot to do. That is the theme of Open world games. As I commonly do in my reviews, I suggest you wait for a sale to purchase this game, if you purchase it... I got my copy of the game on a Humblebundle.

Before you buy, one final note: There are a number of reviews out there on this game saying that this game has been falsely advertised. I cannot speak from experience because I never played this game anywhere else. You're only getting the core game with the Purchase of â€œBurnout Paradise: The Ultimate Boxâ€, in other words if you look up DLC for this game, all of that is unavailable. You cannot even purchase the DLC on steam. For die-hard-Burnout Paradise fans, that's a tough knock. So it's worth noting that you're not getting â€œthe Ultimate Boxâ€, you're just getting the core game.

Conclusion: To quickly recap: Story â€“ not really a selling point. Gameplay â€“ fun, even if you're not very big on car and/or racing games. Very forgiving when you crash early in the game. Achievements â€“ Nonexistent. Price â€“ Fair, I suggest waiting for a sale. Remember â€“ you're only getting the core game.
All in all, this is a fun car game which can be appreciated regardless of how obsessed (or couldn't care less) about cars. I recommend this game for people who enjoy racing games, or want to give a driving game a shot, keep in mind the open world aspect is a big appeal to certain gamers rather then others. (Open world is my favorite)
As always, thanks for reading my review.

reviewText:
Are you looking for a different racing game, or planning to get into the racing genre? Then this might just be the game for you! Burnout Paradise isn't your usual racing game, but will still supply you with hours of fun!

The racing genre has many subcategories, and the burnout franchise might just be an entire subgenre on it's own. You still have the basics like racing of course, but EA has a different look at racing. You can crash into things, crash other racers, make stunts while still aiming for the first place.

Gameplay
The main concept is still the same. You are in a car, dropped in Paradise city, have fun. The physics aren't too different from other games, but I felt that drifting has been kept to a minimum. Which isn't necessarely a bad thing, especially not in a city full of buildings and other cars.

Like I said before, you are able to crash into everything, breakable or unbreakable. Remember however, that it doesn't mean your invincible. At least, not in most events. Fortunately, there are several repair stations around Paradise City so that shouldn't be the biggest of your problems.

You start off with a basic car at a junkyard, and the game will teach you several things before you start the journey. However, it does barely to not teach about the controls, which is something you have to find out yourself unfortunately. If you're familiar with racing games, then this won't be any problem for you, but it may be annoying for new players.

Each car has 3 stats, being Speed, Boost and Strength. It is up to you to seek the best combination which both fits your driving style and is the most useful in events. Events are scattered all around Paradise City, of which I have a few examples below:

Races - I can't make it more obvious. The great thing about Burnout however, is that you decide your own route. That's right, you are not stuck on a set route where you just have to show your skills and prove your the best. Shortcuts and ramps are your best friends in Paradise City.
Road Rages - Personally my favorite of the bunch. Your goal is to take out a set amount of cars in a set amount of time.
Take overs - This has nothing to do with racing whatsoever, but it is still fun. Think of it as a minigame, where your car is like a ball, trying to hit as many objects as possible to get crash dollars, which are mandatory for completing the event. I will admit that this event gets boring after a while, and you have to do this event a lot if you're seeking completion.
When you complete an event, it sometimes occurs that there's a new car racing through the city. You can take it out and add it to your own collection! Also, you get a new car every time you upgrade your license. Your license gets upgraded every time after you have completed a set amount of events.

Presentation
The game is still part of the racing genre, but still does many things different from other games in the same genre. Instead of selecting events, you are racing through Burnout Paradise, which is the overworld itself!

I won't touch the graphics however. Graphics is something strictly personal to people, so I can't give my opinion on that. For me however, the graphics are pretty good and fitting of the game. You can see far ahead of you and I haven't experienced any lagg or framedrops during my playthroughs of the game.

We now have Steam music, but I still want to mention that the music selection in Burnout is pretty good. There is music for everybody, from metal to opera to classic. Of course, there is also the narrator, being the dj of this radio station, who will give you advice during the game.

There are a few things I have to mention, that may not be appealing to several people. For example, cars aren't customizable. The only things you can change to your car are the colours. I personally don't mind this but I can understand that other people do.

To go online, you are also required to have or creat an EA account. It's not too big of an issue, unless you are strictly against it of course.

The final steps
Beating the game isn't too hard. It only requires you to complete events until you got the final license. I would recommend trying to take on as many different events as possible, because otherwise it might become boring/repetitive over time.

Completing the game however, turns out to be a more difficult journey. The game does not have Steam Achievements, but there are in-game achievements called Paradise Awards. They are technically the same as Achievements, only that they won't show up on your Steam profile.

I myself am not a completionist, but it does bother me that the game handles collectables rather poorly. There are Super Jumps, Billboards to destroy and Fences to drive though. Unfortunately, When you achieve a colletable, it does not show up anywhere on the map for example. You will most likely have find them all by the end of the game, but it's still a nitpick which I can't overlook.

Conclusion
Burnout is a really fun game that I would recommend to anyone looking for a new fresh experience. People familiar to the racing genre might find a few nitpicks, but may still find a lot of fun here. And while this may be different from most racing games, this may still be a good starting point for newcomers to the genre.

While not necessary, it is recommended to play this game with a controller/

reviewText: This was one of the original break-em and smash them racing games. My first introduction to the burnout series was Burnout : Revenge for the original xbox. Revenge was action packed and had very smooth game play. This game compared to it's predecessor is good but lacks fluidity and solid core mechanics. I would recommend Flatout Ultimate Carnage over this as it has more mini games, is less of a grind and for me was more engaging. Unlike Flatout, Burnout Paradise let's you explore the open world with some new vehicle types.\n\nParadise city is an open world crash-em-up racer. The gameplay is pretty sound but can have some hiccups here and there regarding fluidity. You may drive around town freely and look and participate any event that is currently available to you. To start events, simply drive up to the event circle and press the gas and brake at the same time. These events come in the forms of Burnout Route/Burnout Ride (specifically for motorcycles) in which you race the clock for modified parts for your car, marked man which you race to a specific point while dodging enemy AI players trying to crash you, road rage mode where players are required to take out a certain amount of cars to proceed, stunt mode where air time, rolls and spins earn you points and finally Road Rules. There are two modes" to road rules : time and showtime rules. Time is like a time attack whereas showtime requires the player to cause as much havoc to traffic as possible. reviewText: Burnout Paradise... hummm... what to think? Awesome game? I'm surprised to hear myself saying this but... no. Are the graphics sweet? Definitely yes and the damage to the cars as you drive really add to it. But no matter how banged up the ride, it doesn't seem to affect performance. Good thing too because the cars are not hard to bang up at all and it's a challenge to finish a race without a scratch. So what's this game missing that makes it miss it's mark with me? Surprisingly it directions. Nothing like being in a race and missing a turn and going from first to last because suddenly you have to back track or find a longer alternate way which by the way you can miss another turn on also. I'm sorry but in a high speed race I can't glance at a map and it's hard enough to notice my own race car's turn signal telling me a turn is coming up. Impossible if the rear fender takes damage. Memorize the streets? Sorry but I can't comment that kind work to a whole digital city. It's just hard to stay in a race if you don't memorize the turns and this city has hundreds of them. But on the plus side the city also has hundreds of short-cuts. Same problem for me again... memorization (Yea I know... misspell.) And some of those short-cuts don't let you off right away so if you take a wrong one, you are definitely out of the race. But the city in this game is beautiful and the cars are works of art and they all have dozens of variations of themselves. When you are racing you definitely feel the speed and as the cars get faster the speed becomes insane. This game falls just short of awesome but I'd recommend it just the same. Even with the headacks of getting lost in a race, it's still fun to play.

I'm not a racing pro nor a big fan of racing games, but i tried a few. I want to start this review with pros & cons, but these are just my opinions.

Pros:
Visuals -- The game is Beautiful --
Open world -- I played with a few NFS titles and Street Racing Syndicate, and i dont remember that any of them had a real open world racing, and I mean racing, not freeroam. Yeah, I was waiting for that open world racing, but i must admit, that sometimes its very confusing, when you dont know where the finish line is. --
Car Damage -- Yeah!!! I like the slowmo car wrecking :) --
And I think thats all of the pros in my opinion. Lets check the cons.

Cons:
UI -- Dafuq!!! No speedometer, no tachometer... Is this a racing game or what? But atleast it has a Nitro bar... excuse me, a Boost bar --
Invisible man -- I know that this is nothing, but this is not Knight Rider... I want a Driver in the driver seat --
Manufacturers -- Just avoid this if you wish, but the car and manufacturer names are irritating me --
Car customizing -- Correct me if im wrong, but the car customization in this game is equal to zero... or almost zero... you can choose from a few colors and paint your car. Maybe I played a bit too much with NFSU 1-2, NFSMW and NFSC, but in a STREET racing game the lack of car customization makes the game rly boring rly fast. And for me the customization, new parts, etc. count as motivation... so yeah i lost my motivation --
Story  -- I know, I know... if I want a story, then I should go and play Skyrim. But even in the NFS titles I mentioned before there were events and there was a main storyline, not so detailed as in an RPG game, but atleast I was motivated, but here... i lost my motivation twice. --
Publisher -- EA... do I have to say more? --
Ingame Store -- Abandoned --
Concluson:

I really enjoyed the first few hours in this game, its an eye candy and sadly its only an eye candy, nothing more. Its the second day I play with this game, and its boring as hell. I know that my most pros and cons that I wrote are small things, but  small things can make the game good or bad. In this case in my opinion the game failed to be a Good game. Its beautiful, but not even close to be good.
To be honest, if u have the chance to win this game on a giveaway, or get it free, then give it a shot, but dont waste any money on it.

reviewText:
Probably still my favourite ever driving game, perhaps tied with Burnout Revenge. The PC port works and plays wonderfully, albeit with a slightly broken store now (you don't get the Toys, Legends cars etc and they're unavailable permanently).

But the game hasn't aged a bit in seven years. It's got tight, fantastic driving controls, the missions are fun, and the free-form world, while it takes a bit of getting used to, is fun to explore and crafted incredibly with beautiful attention to detail on shortcuts, different areas etc. As a fan of collecting stuff in games as well, this game totally appeals to me - forget the events when I can go around smashing through all the shortcut gates, billboards, and jumps in the world while taking in the sights.

For five quid, this is a steal. I paid Â£40 for it originally and have had so much enjoyment out of it I still think I got a bargain.

An awesome game gifted to me by a friend of mine!


This game is not your traditional press-fwd-arrow-and-win-racer, because tracks for the races are not scripted and it is an open-world race. You have to know the map like the back of your hand, or constantly open the map menu to draw an imaginary track for your competition, which can get absurdly annoying while you are flying against the oncoming traffic.

At the beginning it is all ok, because the cars that you own are not so fast- you can predict your turns more easily and pass by the traffic, but later on it gets absurdly hard to get to the first place because of the high speeds.

reviewText:
Okay so Burnout Paradise is really fun but I feel like it has lots of missed potential. Hear me out.
- The open world concept is a really good idea, but it doesn't make a lot of sense to then focus all the attention in 8 points of the world map. You're basically making every other place look uninteresting.
- You can pick up events all over the map... Or the city should I say, since the areas outside the city almost have none. That makes the areas outside the city uninteresting. After driving through the roads a couple of times I wouldn't have many reasons to return.
- Having everything taking place in the city makes the map feel cramped and hard to navigate through. Burnout is not a game in which I want to go slowly so I don't miss anything.
- Good luck exploring a whole city without turn by turn navigation. Nobody wants to open a world map while driving. No, the road signs are not enough.
- The events in the city make you leave the city almost all of the time. Which means that if you want to play another event you'll probably need to return to the city, and that feels like a loss of time for the player. You should never make the player feel like their time doesn't matter, especially after rewarding them for clearing an event.
- The events start to feel repetitive after a while. Even if there are many types of events, if you are always racing to the same place, it gets kind of boring.
- It doesn't matter how high you score in an event since the only thing the game acknowledges is if you passed or not. A rank system would have made the experience a lot more interesting.
- The menus don't feel natural at all, especially the d-pad menu. This menu demands your attention while driving (or even while an event takes place), and unless you stop the vehicle there's no way to drive and navigate through the menu without crashing. It doesn't make sense to put the Restart last event" option in a place like that.
- There's no explicit way to exit an event. You have to stop the car. I had to Google this. That is not good design.
- The way to start an event leads to many accidental starts. You can't expect me not to push accelerate + brake in a turning point for any other reason than starting an event.
- The classical music feels like a bad joke that was funny only the very first time. It doesn't fit in the mood of the rest of the game.
- The idea of including different types of cars and adding motorbikes was nice
date: but poorly executed. It takes way too much time to find a junkyard and then change the vehicle for a certain event
recommended: not that it matters anyway because at least for now every vehicle seems to be fit for every kind of event. It makes me wonder why make different types of cars in the first place and not make just one kind. If you are going to make different profiles of playable entities at least give me a reason to use them. Choices should have a meaning in the mechanics
hoursPlayed:
apart from the way the vehicle earns boost.
- The respawn algorithm is just awful. Don't respawn me in front of a wall. Don't respawn me in front of a jump.
- Takedowns don't feel as rewarding as they used to in other games of the series. Where is Impact Time? Why can't you do multiple takedowns at the same time?
- No windowed mode?

Don't get me wrong

reviewText:
When people say that Burnout Paradise was a high point in the last generation (as of 2014) of racing games, it's not hyperbole or due to a large amount of cash. It's because it's that good.

The gameplay is still extremely fun by today's standards, and so are the graphics. There is just so much to find in the city, be it races, parking garages, Super Jump ramps, drive-throughs and those pesky fences and billboards. Be prepared to spend hours trying to beat your friends' Road Rule scores as well.

The motorcycles are certainly a welcome addition to the game, adding a whole new learning experience to the gameplay due to the different manner bikes and cars behave. If only they had released the other DLC on PC or at least bothered keeping the Burnout Store online...

If you ever have to limit youself to just one arcade racing game, make it this one.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game, Nice open-world experience, fantastic graphics, nice idea on how to unlock new cars and bikes. it's a great game. It's nice to see a game released where you can drive around exploring an open area, some games have that but they're not as fun to explore as Burnout Paradise. if you've played Burnout Revenge, and you remembered all 8 of the maps, this game combines all 8 of those maps from Burnout Revenge into one huge area you can explore. there's only one thing that makes it a little disappointing: there's orchestra music. I'm a huge fan of the burnout series and this is the first burnout game that has orchestra music. That's not burnout, Burnout's music is mainly techno, dance, or rock music. It's not all orchestra music, there is some techno, dance, and rock music in this game,  so it's not all that bad.

Graphics: beautiful, this game runs great on my PC, no lag at all, graphics at high-resolution look great, better than on the console.[my PC specs are in my showcase box description]

Gameplay: smooth driving mechanic, very fun to drift around curve's and earn points in stunt events. It's nice to see interest points, like a repair shop where you can repair your car, a gas station where you can refill your boost, and places to paint your car even though the paint is selected for you at random. Also, some goals set out in the open world, like short cuts, Burnout Paradise bild boards you can break, and ramps where you can get high air jumps. which is a very cool idea if you're just exploring paradise city you can complete those tasks while your doing it. One thing it does need for the mechanic is a spedometer, that's about it.

I'm going to score this game a 9/10, Best open-world racing game I've played yet. I'm a huge fan of the burnout series and I'm very happy that this game to be in the burnout series.

reviewText:
Summary: There's lots of stuff to do. If you like racing games, you'll like this one. It's non-stop addictive. One of EA's last good games.

After picking it up with the EA Humble Bundle last year, I couldn't stop. There was just so much to do. You start smashing fences for a while and suddenly, a billboard comes into your vision. That billboard's going down. Get some air, bam, full boost, billboard down. So you boost around the city, smashing more fences, looking for those sick blue cone jumps, and soon you unlock some sort of trophy-award type thing. What is this? Searching through the arguably worst menu in history, I find the list of awards. The award you just got is about smashing something like 200 or 300 fences, and you discover that there are more awards! Some for jumps, some for takedowns, some for online things which EA really sucks at, and BILLBOARDS. You look around the map for billboards. Some you can't reach, and you have to figure a way to get to it. After defeating the evil red billboards, beat up all the yellow fences, you come home victorious to the junk yard.

Then you start your first race.

reviewText:
video game (feat. video & aggro lavine's boyfrend song)

good physics but hard to appreciate. they stuck with the idea of never teleporting the player so objectives are generally easy enough to not need to retry. a LOT of time will be spent watching cars crash into things in ultra-slowmo. can't turn it off even though multiplayer disables it.

the map is nicely designed but the graphics dont do it any favors. even important parts of the road blend into the unsaturated scenery. there's a few hundred things to jump and crash into for completionists. the whole area is unlocked from the start and never changes so it does get stale.

progression feels slow and repetitive: complete # objectives, reset map with slightly more difficult AI, rinse and repeat. unlocking cars is the main reason to continue; they're decently varied and each with an upgraded version to get.

dont forget the EA-mandatory condescending announcer guy telling you how to press a button, and unskippable opening logos. also audio options dont take effect until you gain control of your car so i hope you like ACDC's viridian city blaring each time you open it.

reviewText:
I'd say that, for a PC Racing Game, this is pretty good... but not perfect.

For the good, i will say the controls work pretty well with both Keyboard and Gamepad. Of course, the gamepad works a bit better, but it's one of the few PC racing games i can say i'd actually play with the keyboard.

Secondly, the open world is fantastic. It's really large, open to exploration, and just damn fun to drive around in.

And finally, all the cars feel unique. Even the clones of the same car, such as the Customs, still feel really good, even different compared to the regular version.

But it does have some problems.

Not gonna complain about the dlc, but what i will complain about, is the CRASHING. I don't mean Car Crashing, i mean the Game Crashing. It happens randomly, and there are no signs it is going to happen, just one second you're happily driving along, the next, the game crashes. And it happens ALL THE DAMN TIME.

Secondly, while it looks great, there are some texture quality problems at times. That's all i'll say about it.

I personally can say that i have enjoyed this game quite a good bit, but it's not without faults. I'd reccommend buying it if you have the spare money.

reviewText:
Heres the plot of this game for those that dont know.
You spawn in the game as a sentient car, who must race many, many races against other Sentient cars, you can respawn, but they cannot, after winning races, there will sometimes be a car you must destroy, once destroyed you can transform into the other car. You may also roam around the city and county(?) areas as you please, destroying anything in your way with no mercy. As you level up, you destroy better and better cars, and have the ability to transform into them. Once you are an elite with the car, you may transform into a gold or platnum car, showing your hyper-awesome-I-am-elite status, all the cars around you will be jellyous. Sometimes, you may join what you think is a race... but you get zombie cars chasing you and ramming you instead, it gets scary, really scary, make sure you dont go down though.. or it's game over for life!


Once you are at the highest-super-hyper-whateveritis-elite level, DJ Atomica(the only living human) congratulates you...
There is, however, a twist ending... Which I wont ruin.. you have to play the game to know...

reviewText:
Burnout Paradise is the racing game for the players that also want turn their oponents into wrecks.

The game starts off with some lady saying: 'welcome to Paradise City'. (It's the hub world) It's awsome! Now do whatever you want and have fun!

After that you are dropped into the garage or rather the wrecking yard and given a blue trashed looking muscle. Turns out your new half broken car works as good as new. While all this is happening you are being told, or rather hinted at, what to do by DJ Atomica. He's the guy who was the radio anouncer in SSX3.

If you have no idea who the guy is, he is basically your average cheesy amrican dj who, unlike in SSX3 (really good snow boarding game), is a jerk to you in this game.

And although I can see where the game designers were coming from, they tried too hard in making him the 'tough love get backup on your feet guy' and made him a jerk instead.

The good news is, he is just there to give you hints and tips that you don't need, so just turn the speech volume to zero as no one else ever talks.

Now back to the game play. (Note, this only covers the single player, as multiplayer needs an EA acount to work and I know what that means to some people, cough cough.) And it's some good game play, allright. For starters every single car in the game has boost (AKA nitros) and even the first one can get some serious speed going.

There are also 3 types of cars: stunt, race and takedown. Stunt, first off, is the basic one. Do crazy stuff like driving on the wrong side of the road, near misses, slamming civilans ect,  to get boost and use boost to go fast... realy fast!

Then there's racers. Racers can't use their boost bar unless it's full. But using the boost until its empty is called a burnout. Burnouts fill at least half (usally more) of the boost bar, meaning that when combined together with reckless driving will let you do burnout after burnout, making you go much faster and further then a stunt car could ever go.

Only downsides are: 1# as explained before, the boost bar MUST be full to be used. #2 racers usally have worse turning than stunt, so you may end up crashing into something ( CURSE YOU BUSSES!) and losing all your boost. And 3# racers are weaker than the  other 2 types of cars, so it's harder to get take-downs with them.(Take-downs will be explained just about now.)

Lastly are take-down cars: they are the slowest but the strongest of the lot. With take-down cars you have a smaller boost bar to start off with than stunt cars, but the bar can be made up to 3 as big by getting take-downs.
Causing your opponent to crash in any way, is called a take down. There are many ways you can take someone down, so heres a sample list: slamming them into a wall, landing on top of the poor fool, ramming into the back of them so the foe crashes into a  bus/other foe/brickwall, scraping the foe against a wall for so long that the in-game physics says that's it
date: I'm outa here!" and the foe flips over the side railing and gets turned into scrapyard modern art. And so on...\n\nThen there's  the physics system which decides that you are awsome and that your foes suck. So them grinding you against a wall or ramming your behind will not kill you
recommended: but you will kill them when it's the other way around. This makes you feel like an awsome badass that cannot be stopped.\n\nThen there's the game types. 1# races. Races are the most simple. Get from point A to point B
hoursPlayed: only you can get take-downs the whole way. The early races are easy-ish but get harder and harder as time goes on until they get a tad frustrating. Just make sure you bring the map up(can be found in key bindings) and plot your course before you race.\n\nAlso

In this mode

reviewText:
Great fun, one of the few non-Kart racing games that I truly enjoy playing.  The music selection is wonderful, the car selection is great, and online play is perfection!  Only down side is not as many people online as there used to be, but that is to be expected from a game of this age.  Oh, and the car crashes... those wonderful car crashes... they are the best part.  It's like a city-wide demolition derby and it is as fun as that sounds!

One note, if you get a blank white screen when going online, just close it.  It's a leftover from when EA actually supported it with an online store.  Now that the store is gone, all that's left is a blank screen.  It's annoying at first, but you learn to ignore it soon enough.

Played using a Logitech E-X5D12 Driving Force Feedback Wireless Wheel Controller.  I had to remap the controls in the game, they were awful, but once it's configured, the experience is amazing!

reviewText:
Game #4 - Burnout Paradise: Ultimate Edition (PC)

November 5, 2014
In the world of Racing games, the Burnout series is more about creating chaos and less about the racing skill. This type of experience is not unique to just racing; in Football games you have NFL Blitz, and Basketball has NBA JAM. As with the others, Burnout Paradise offers over-the-top speed, jumps and crashes. This entire experience is similar enough to it's predecessors, but offers players the newer concept of exploration in an Open World environment. The updated game design, graphics and expanded multiplayer makes this a game that needs to be played.

The overall experience of Burnout Paradise is somewhat discounted from the other games in the series. Luckily this was neither a good or bad move on an already fun game, but a choice to try and update for the future of the franchise. Although there are changes like the Open World exploration, a majority of events made there way to to Paradise. Players can stop at many traffic singles and hold LT and RT to begin events like Racing, Wanted Man and Takedown. Additionally, there are events specific to each vehicle, which are acquired by taking down cars after major races. The final addition to Paradise was the introduction of Motorcycles. While not as simple as cars to maneuver through the city; they create a unique challenge for even the most seasoned Burnout racer.

Burnout Paradise release on January 22nd, 2008 for the Xbox 360 and PS3. A little over a year later EA brought it to PC on February 8th, 2009. At full price of $59.99 many people would have snatched it up immediately. This also lends to the Metacritic score of 87 making it a very well received game. In my experience, which is being familiar with the franchise and game mechanic, I would give it a solid 8. In today's market, you can probably pick up the Consolehttp://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/burnout-paradise-the-ultimate-box Edition for $15-$20, and depending on the PC key sale, you can pick up the Ultimate Box edition for less than $10.  Well worth the money, the introduction of Open  World exploration, and the quick and painless way to find a new race event, made this a better experience.



FoG

reviewText:
It's some great old-school racing fun, with a ton of content for a very small price.

You have an upgrade path with lots of cars in three main groups: speed, stunt and destruction. You collect these as you win races and challenges, both as rewards and as target which you have to take down in order to collect them.

You can play offline with challenges from simple races, not-so-simple races, stunt challenges and races where you are the target for other cars who are trying to destroy your vehicle.

You can also play online with friends and strangers, setting up races, simple ones or with multiple check points, car limits, boost limits or a free-for all. You will need a free EA/Origin account to play online and to add friends to your friends list requires installing Origin.

There are some annoying quirks (the UI navigation involves ESC, F1, F2 and Backspace!) and the theme song that plays every time you launch the game (To stop it: Go to Steam\steamapps\common\Burnout(TM) Paradise The Ultimate Box\SOUND\STREAMS and replace the file GUNS_AND_ROSES.SNS with a blank text file of the same name (including extension)) and there's this blank page that pops up requiring you to hit Return to Game" every so often in the menu (The fix to that is to add  127.0.0.1 portal.burnoutweb.ea.com to your hosts file). I guess that's some hangover they forgot to fix when they stopped supporting whatever was on that page
recommended: it's plain sailing.\n\nIt's a good little game!"

reviewText:
I honestly can't put into words how awesome this game is.

Everything about it is perfect... the open world to the car selection - I am just stunned.

I really wish developers nowdays would look at what Criterion Games did to make this a timeless masterpiece.

I can see myself 10 years from now still going back to play this ;)

Short pros and cons list below.

++ Pros ++
+ Open world
+ Over 70 cars
+ Perfect arcade car physics and behaivour
+ Very nice graphics for a game back in '08
+ Seems to be well optimized
+ Online multiplayer is awesome
+ Lots of game modes
+ The world has lots of cool spots to go and many jumps and billboards to smash
+ Awesome car damage and slow-mo crash cameras :D

-- Cons --
- The Big Surf Island DLC never came to PC (but you can get a hack that puts it in the game anyway)
- The Burnout in-game store no longer works, but you can buy most of the DLC off Amazon now (Toy Cars, Legendary Cars, Timesaver's Pack etc)
- No text chat online, only voice chat.
- Theres a guy called ElvisAlive007 who is a real pain in the butt. Make sure you kick him as soon as he connects :D


If you like arcade racers this is the game for you ;)

reviewText: Burnout Paradise is a game that has taken the open world elements that we have all loved from the past, along with a racing game tied into the formula. Not only does Burnout give players an open world, but uses a great way to unlock cars. There are many ways to unlock cars. From performing the same old race to driving down the highway to smash a rival that is in pursuit, Paradise is very edgy and also easy for players to level up and climb the ranks. Along with the open world and unlockable items, Burnout allows players to experience driving in a whole new level with a Slow-Motion camera designed to see crashes or takedowns in a whole new way. This feature actually makes crashing a little more rewarding (as weird as it sounds) than that of just completing a race. With a great Single-Player along with a fun Multiplayer  Burnout is a must have title in anybody's library.\n

reviewText:
PROS:
-fun racing game

-huge dynamic map with a good amount of places to explore, going through the same road or street twice will never be the same experience

-takedown system has been changed since latest burnout games in a way which I personally dislike



Overall is worth getting this game on sale and just beat it using the cars that the game itself gives you through upgranding your license and unlocking and such, paying more than 3 euros for this is a wrong decision and purchasing anything in the store is even worse

reviewText:
One of the best racing games out there. No matter how many years have passed since it launched, I still come back to it to have fun racing and crashing cars.

HOWEVER, beware many people, including myself, are having problems starting up the game. I believe the game servers shutdown, and ever since it's been a pain to get it working.

Startup game homepage (there is an ingame browser that starts everytime you start the game, before opening the actual game) is broken, so working around this to get the game working is a painful process, unless criterion releases a game patch.

In the mean time, go to the file burnoutparadise.exe location (right click in steam game, properties, browse file location), and then in windows explorer right click the burnoutparadise.exe file, set it in compatibility with windows xp sp3, and that will do it. It did it for me, after a research on the web on how to make it work.

If you have the option to get this game on console, is a different story. The consoles work with no problem (ps3 and xbox 360), but the game will not be as beautiful as it is on PC. It's your choice.

One of my favorite racing games of all time.

reviewText:
Yeah, it was made 5 years ago.
So what?

Graphics are still amazing.
This is the single best open world driving game I've ever played!
Online multiplayer so you can drive around with your friends and smash each other to bits.
If I had found out about this earlier, I would have thought it'd be too good to be true!
The open world is so good that the only reason I do missions anymore is when A) I want to change things up a bit, or B) I want to unlock more cars.
There are tons of different cars, and playstyles, if you want to be a super fast formula car, or just an unstoppable wall that noone can hit without being taken out. Or maybe you want to be a sports car, with enough speed to keep your car out of trouble while still looking fantastic.
The music is awesome. Just the kinds of things you want to listen to when smashing your way through downtown Paradise.

Definitely the best racing game I've ever played!

reviewText: Online population is next to dead and full regulars that exploit or outright cheat. But still, online/offline there is plenty to do in this game. There are three event types (race, stunt run, and road rage [online has challenges outside of these]) and 50+ cars consisting of three types (boost, rage, and stunt) that change how you play to fill up your boost. Your car selection is limited in online events (race, stunt, and rage), but has no restriction in Freeburn (online no event) and while doing online challenges. Offline play usu. requires specific vehicles to complete progress (i.e. dependent on event type). Regardless of online or offline play the entire map is completely open. Online you work with others to complete achievements or participate in events and offline you work to unlock cars.\n\nThe only issue is that the game will disconnect players from host (no dedicated servers) at times when the hosts start events, most regularly during races. Challenges do not seem to be effected by this issue. And there is no in-game chat ability other than a mic, which, thankfully, you have the ability to mute players if their mic has feedback or they are trolling.

reviewText:
Back in my PS2 days I owned Burnout 2 and Takedown and loved the games - played them to bits. When I saw this was up for grabs on a  Steam sale I jumped at the chance.

The game is not quite what I was expecting. It's very different to what I thought it would be. That's not to say some of the changes are not for the better, but on the other hand, some aren't.

Graphics look brilliant, and the cars still have that same Burnout feel" to them. The game modes all make a return too - but this time in an open world map. Think NFSU 2 and you will be on the right tracks. This is great
date: but you seem to spent a lot of time driving around for no reason. I would much prefer to just race and perform the stages without this unnecessary addition. The races themselves also suffer from the same problem of being given too much freedom - you will accidentally go the wrong way because you are concentrating on driving and not constantly looking at the map.\n\nO yes
recommended: and no 2 player split screen? Not good :-(\n\nBar the problems I have with it though
hoursPlayed: it's still a good game. Burnout fans will find something to their liking here.\n\nJimbo Rating: 5/10"

Or you're like me and like crashing into â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and watching it tumble around, that's what road rage mode is for. Also, you can just activate this mode where your car suddenly starts flipping and the objective is to cause as much damage to other cars before you loose momentum.

This game still plays as good as when it came out and hasn't felt any older. The world is so big, some people can still get lost in the middle of a heated race in multiplayer. The variety of cars is there and each one drives really differently.

I would buy it now since it still has people playing it.

reviewText:
So good!!!  Still my favorite game of all time.  Open world racing, spectacular crashes, awesome soundtrack.

Vehicles: Cars handling is very arcade-y, but very fun.  There are a number of cars with twitchy handling that require more than just throttle mashing to win the races.  A Burning Route time trial event for each car unlocks a slightly upgraded version of that car.  The addition of motorcycles is a nice change of pace with their offline time trial events.

Stunt Runs, Road Rages, Marked Man and Race events can be played online or offline.  In addition, there are hundreds of online challenges for 2-8 players.  When you find a good group of online players, it is a lot of fun.

Showtime: Crash your way down the road racking up as many points as possible.  Destruction has never been more fun.
Road Rules: Set a fast time for every road on the map.  You'll be cursing the traffic but that clean run is so sweet.

Criterion, please take a break from Need for Speed and make another Burnout already.

Sidenote:  I played this game all the way through to 102% on the PS3 in 2009 and just recently bought it for the PC.  It looks SO much better on the PC.

reviewText:
It's some great old-school racing fun, with a ton of content for a very small price.

You have an upgrade path with lots of cars in three main groups: speed, stunt and destruction. You collect these as you win races and challenges, both as rewards and as target which you have to take down in order to collect them.

You can play offline with challenges from simple races, not-so-simple races, stunt challenges and races where you are the target for other cars who are trying to destroy your vehicle.

You can also play online with friends and strangers, setting up races, simple ones or with multiple check points, car limits, boost limits or a free-for all. You will need a free EA/Origin account to play online and to add friends to your friends list requires installing Origin.

There are some annoying quirks (the UI navigation involves ESC, F1, F2 and Backspace!) and the theme song that plays every time you launch the game (To stop it: Go to Steam\steamapps\common\Burnout(TM) Paradise The Ultimate Box\SOUND\STREAMS and replace the file GUNS_AND_ROSES.SNS with a blank text file of the same name (including extension)) and there's this blank page that pops up requiring you to hit Return to Game" every so often in the menu (The fix to that is to add  127.0.0.1 portal.burnoutweb.ea.com to your hosts file). I guess that's some hangover they forgot to fix when they stopped supporting whatever was on that page
recommended: it's plain sailing.\n\nIt's a good little game!"

reviewText:
Great fun, one of the few non-Kart racing games that I truly enjoy playing.  The music selection is wonderful, the car selection is great, and online play is perfection!  Only down side is not as many people online as there used to be, but that is to be expected from a game of this age.  Oh, and the car crashes... those wonderful car crashes... they are the best part.  It's like a city-wide demolition derby and it is as fun as that sounds!

One note, if you get a blank white screen when going online, just close it.  It's a leftover from when EA actually supported it with an online store.  Now that the store is gone, all that's left is a blank screen.  It's annoying at first, but you learn to ignore it soon enough.

Played using a Logitech E-X5D12 Driving Force Feedback Wireless Wheel Controller.  I had to remap the controls in the game, they were awful, but once it's configured, the experience is amazing!

reviewText:
This game is still the best racing game available to the public, in my opinion. Criterion Games may be making the NFS series now, but they can't seem to replicate the awesome intensity of this game, not by a long shot.

Paradise City is a big open box of fun, where whatever route you want to take to get to the finish line, is up to you.
None of this horsing around with the side routes you aren't allowed on, if there's a path, it goes somewhere, and it's just waiting for you to find out just where that is.

Burnout: Paradise follows a single, simple racing law...
If you're not in first. Get there.
If you're in first, stay there.

This game doesn't bother you with a clunky HUD and a speedometer, letting you know that you're traveling faster than everyone else, from last place. There's no rear-view mirror, blocking your view of what dangers might lie before you.
You have one objective, win the race. And staring at your speedometer, watching the soccer moms in the mirror won't help you obtain that objective in the least.

Race.
Race Faster.
Win.

What a fantastic game.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER!!!!!!! This DOES NOT include any DLC despite what the title says.

I have been a huge fan of the entire Burnout series from day one it is an amazing arcade style game with a ton of different races and modes.
Burnout Paradise is by far the most different of them all, think of it as Need for Speed (Carbon/Most wanted) and Burnout had a baby this is that baby unlike other Burnout games when you finish a race the game doesnt go back to any menus or anything it puts ou back into an open world where you can drive around doing whatever you want until you decide to race again which i always loved in the Need for Speed games that had it.
But like I said this is not the ultimate box so if you are buying it expecting DLC then just stay away but it is the base Burnout Paradise game which is an amazing game by itself idk if the online modes work or not I dont mess with those but the party play is fun if you have friends over and want to play each other.
The soundtrack like all other burnout games is awesome and the world and cars are beautiful this one really shows the damage done to your car better than ever before and the slow motion crash cam is great.
I recomend it if you are ok with not having the DLC I suggest getting it on sale though but thats a given with any and all games to me.

This game is great fun, absolutely.

reviewText:
This game is getting older as we speak. The game is a classic and is really the best Burnout game in the series, I love this game personally and can play it for hours with its multiple missions and many different cars. The cars in this game... Well I love them really, starting the cars driving them at high speeds through the city and the hills. There are many DLCs ,which you know I hate, but there is a definate way to bypass that. The cars are all interesting and really fun to drive, the handling is very easy and you can definatley feel the freedom when you're driving.

Firstly the cars in this are awesome! You can get many styles of cars such as: Rage, stunt, street and that wierd turbo thing that only lets you recharge... The entire car system has many different styles of driving, the cars can be stock or the upgraded unlocked version of the original car. You can get mini cars, police cars and many more random types of new cars which can only be found on the origin store. The DLC for paradise island is only avalible for the console versions of this game but you can mod it into the game which adds buggys and a whole new island. The entire games map is massive compared to new games and its nicley detailed, the whole thing has events placed at every intersection" as explained in the first part of the game which is true! Events on every intersection which can be played again but only to beat your score.

The map concludes of beaches

The game that's on top of my racing game list. This is just so brilliant game where you have an open world even during races! That's something that I like quite a lot. reviewText:
This game is still the best racing game available to the public, in my opinion. Criterion Games may be making the NFS series now, but they can't seem to replicate the awesome intensity of this game, not by a long shot.

Paradise City is a big open box of fun, where whatever route you want to take to get to the finish line, is up to you.
None of this horsing around with the side routes you aren't allowed on, if there's a path, it goes somewhere, and it's just waiting for you to find out just where that is.

Burnout: Paradise follows a single, simple racing law...
If you're not in first. Get there.
If you're in first, stay there.

This game doesn't bother you with a clunky HUD and a speedometer, letting you know that you're traveling faster than everyone else, from last place. There's no rear-view mirror, blocking your view of what dangers might lie before you.
You have one objective, win the race. And staring at your speedometer, watching the soccer moms in the mirror won't help you obtain that objective in the least.

Race.
Race Faster.
Win.

What a fantastic game.

reviewText:
Burnout Paradise seems to be the kind of sandbox game where strolling around, breaking things and sort of just spending time was a bigger aim than completing missions and getting somewhere storywise. Racing events are challenging enough to be fun but won't test your skills to the limit. The real pleasure comes from speeding, drifting, jumping and ramming fellow racers.

+ A great fun-fueled atmosphere
+ Rich, beautiful environment
+ Interesting challenges
+ Good variety of cars

- The soundtrack/ music selection can get a little tedious
- Game menu is a little cryptic and confusing
- Non-rotating minimap is a challenge to get used to
- No other option to restart a race than to drive back to the starting point
- Some of the game events aren't as self-explanatory as the developers might have thought they were

Verdict:
If you are looking for a not-that-serious 'party' game to sink a few hours into then Burnout Paradise might be a thing for you. Spent a lot of good time playing it, so definitely thumbs up.

reviewText:
Burnout is my favorite racing franchise of all time, I've played the previous titles and loved them to bits. Quite literally. I was always astounded at how beautiful (ironically) crashes in the game can be. The crash physics are wonderful and smashing into cars in road rage is a very pleasant feeling to me. The cars in the game are for the most part, unique and handle differently. Some cars cannot turn fast, forcing you to use the handbrake at sharp corners, and there are some cars that slip and slide everywhere, making it easy to swerve into oncoming traffic, but can drift without issues at sharp turns. The drifting in this game feels amazing; especially when you're driving real fast in a race late in the game when you get the really fast cars.

There are 5 different race types in this game: Race, Road Rage, Stunt Run, Marked Man, and Burning Route all of which are special in their own way.

Races (AKA: Point A to Point B) always make you feel like you're going fast, and doing multiple burnout chains is satisfying. Stunt runs are what they are implied to be, just jump off ramps, boost, and drift to rack up points (these are my least favorite). Road Rage is basically a timed, fast paced demolition derby, and holy crap, it is awesome! Just wreck other drivers and reach the takedown score to win. Marked Man is a bit of a spin on Races and Road Rage. In Marked Man you have to race from point A to point B. The catch is there are drivers trying to prevent you from reaching your target by smashing your car, survive till the finish and you win. Burning Routes are probably the simplest to grasp, just make it to the finish in time and win an upgraded version of the car you're using.

The core game is fantastic in and of itself, however I think it would be best for everyone if I mention how well the online portion of the game is. Freeburn online is a very enjoyable experience if the host actually makes the experience fun for everybody. What I mean is when you're playing online the host can make events that everyone can participate in, and these while limited are very enjoyable when alot of players partcipate. Marked man online is so much more thrilling than offline in my opinion, especially when there are 7 players trying their best to take you down. There are loads of challenges that the players can particpate in, and the challenges change with the amount of players, so there's always something to do.

(As far as I know, you can't join a friend's server via steam, you have to it from in game, via the search option.)

The thing to watch out for is that this game does NOT come with all the DLC. The Ultimate Box" just gives you access to two online only cars

reviewText:
Graphics
Well detailed game. You can read (albeit dangerous) the license plates on other cars. The lighting from the sun shines off high gloss paint jobs like in real life. The small detail damages are realistic; if you broke a headlamp it stays broken and doesnâ€™t light up. The back ground is realistic enough to tell distance. Iâ€™ve played this at both regular television and hi definition 1080p while it is still good at the lowest setting I highly recommend the playing at the highest possible detail.

Sound and Music
You can tell from just driving around what types of cars are around you with even having to look at that area. The screeching of the tires to the roar of an engine is clear with any vehicle you use. Now the music, quantity or quality wise you will not be disappointed. There are a lot of songs that play while driving around so chances are if you play for an hour or two, you will not hear the same song twice. And you donâ€™t like a particular song you can always take if off the play list. One should note that a good portion of songs are the same songs from older Burnout Games.

Game Play
As you win events you upgrade your license. The higher the license, the larger amount of vehicles you will be able to use. These events are littered all thought Paradise City. To start the event simple pull up to a light to start it.

Here is the events.

Races: Standard Race. From one to seven other opponents you drive to a specific end point.
Road Rage: Timed Event. You use your vehicle as a battering ram to smash other vehicles into traffic, walls or other hard objects. Target amount is usually displayed. Event ends when either you take to much damage or time ends.

Marked Man: Almost like a race. You goal is to reach one destination while four other computer cars try to inflict enough damage to keep you from reaching your destination.

Stunts: Use your vehicle like a little acrobat, jumping off ramps, crashing bill boards and doing spins. The more you do in a sequence the more points you get. There is a target score to get per event.

Burning Route: One route per vehicle. Itâ€™s a timed race where you just have to get to the finish line by a certain time using a certain vehicle. Every route you finish unlocks a upgraded version of the vehicle used.
All these events get a bit more difficult as the game wears on but not that much more. I would say once you get used to the way the game plays you find that most of these events range from easy (one or two attempts) to medium (fifteen minutes maximum).

Now there are a few side events or tasks that are fun to do. Running certain billboards, barriers, and super jumps. They are littered everywhere, cant be avoided just driving around. There are few hidden but find to fun all of them and as a reward for finding all it unlocks more vehicles. There are also two events per street, one is time trails and the other is showtime. Showtime is just you bouncing around hitting vehicles for points.

Online play is quite fun with tasks and races, connections are usually stable. One thing I like is with Xbox Live Vision take a photo of you when you get taken out by another drive and sent to the aggressor. The online experience is a whole new game in itself and worth playing.

Negatives
Although itâ€™s a very good game here is a few of the things I didnâ€™t like. Showtime is very repetitive in the sense you have to do it to all 64 streets of Paradise City. Also Showtime replaced Crash from previous games. The on line challenges are very repetitive where if 2 players you have to do it for 7 players. And some of them are very very basic like driving in oncoming traffic. Also while doing online challenges if one person get disconnected, the challenges are cancelled. The difficulty level is somewhat misleading as the more cars you unlock the easier the game is when trying to do the events.
One last thing that kind of surprised me is the amount of advertising in the game, from billboards to vans there is way too much advertising in this game. To show how much advertising there are four unlockable cars, all of them are plastered with the names.

reviewText:
Of all the racing games I've ever owned, I have to say this one has been the most fun!

It feels like the game Need For Speed: Most Wanted really wanted to be but just didn't quite hit the mark.  It's typical Burnout: silly, crazy fun with lots of different race modes in a gorgeous open-world.  Unlock better cars at junkyards, learn bigger and better stunts, beat the fastest record for a myriad set of roads or survive brutal races where you must smash a given number of cars out of the race.  For those who find bikes more fun, this is two games in one!  You can start the game in car or motorbike mode instead, with just as many stunts and unlocks to achieve.

This game is also fun for people who don't generally enjoy racing sims.  It's very much arcade-style yet car handling is great with a variety of camera modes to choose from.  The AI is really well made (no rubber-banding or artificial 'cheating' that AI opponents in other games can display).  The difficulty level increases gradually and at the right pace.  It's all enormous fun, light-hearted yet challenging in all the right places.

The only problem I've experienced with the game is getting my G27 Logitech Wheel working nicely with it.  People can and do have success, but my wheel has a continuous, strong pull to the left in this game which I cannot resolve.  Your success might vary, and this article[solidlystated.com] (http://solidlystated.com/software/logitech-g27-burnout-paradise/) is essential reading to get your wheel recognised and configured correctly.  Alas, my wheel pull was too much so I stick to a very old and loved Microsoft Sidewinder stick or my XB360 gamepad - still great fun!

reviewText: Burnout Paradise was a surprise for me. And a good one at that. bought it for around a dollar, didn't expect alot from the game, but what i found was one of the most enjoyable racing experiences i have ever had, up there with need for speed most wanted 2005. The physics in the game are really well made, and the chrashes are as cinematic as it gets, for one of the first times i actually enjoyed crashing my cars, so i could see it getting smashed in slow motion. Crashing was never so fun. Do not mind my lack of hours i have Burnout:Paradise on my Playstation3 and i played it alot more than i have on PC !

But over all i would recommend this game for burnour fans , it is on the best titles Burnout has ever released , but it kinda sucks that they stopped taking care of the game :/

reviewText: I'll be completely honest here, I installed this with pretty low hopes. I've seen what Criterion have done to the NFS franchise, which wasn't exactly stellar but it was fun, and figured they'd done more of the same with the Burnout series. But I am really enjoying this so far. The driving is direct and responsive, taking down an aggro car with a speed car is super satisfying too, that slow mo crash gives you that much loved moment of smugness. Graphically it's quite pretty for its year and it runs really well even on low end machines. So in summation, it's a damn fun game, the shelf life to cost ratio is damn high too. I'd recommend this game to anyone that enjoys racing games and those that enjoy a good hit and run, arcade style racer too.

reviewText: This is easily one of the best, if not the best street racing game that I've ever played. It has excellent car detail and crash physics for its time, and promises hours upon hours of gameplay with new events at every corner. This product automatically comes with the Motorbike DLC from the Burnout Store, so that's an added plus for additional content. I just wish this game was integrated into Steam more, such as mirroring the in-game achievements with Steam Achievements, making the DLCs puchasable though the Steam Store, and adding Steam Trading Cards. Other than the separation from Steam-exclusive features, this game will always be at the top of my list for racing games.

reviewText:
One of the better racing games I've played on steam, despite some serious flaws.

What it is:
- All races played in the overworld
- Traffic is present
- No car upgrades, customization, or tuning
- Car handling is arcade, not simulation
- Several game modes, but only two (race and stunt) are worth playing
- Most time is spent driving, not in menus
- Exploration and finding secret sortcuts plays a big part

Cons:
- Unskippable crash cam gets very annoying very quickly
- No way to instantly restart a race. If you want to retry a race YOU MUST DRIVE BACK TO THE STARTING LINE.
- Repairing your car or switching cars between races requires driving to a repair shop or junkyard, which is extremely tedious.
- The menus are incredibly unintuitive (I had to google search to figure out how to quit the game and how to quit an event)

Pros:
- Exploration and finding secrets is really rewarding
- The stunts are just awesome
- Car handling is good
- It is fun, despite the cons.

reviewText: Preface: the game is perfectly enjoyable on its own merits. You should know, however, that it takes place in a post-apocalyptic world in which the human race has been utterly eradicated by a race of sentient vehicles who now freely roam the streets and occasionally rally terrifying black-clad death squads to murder each other for no apparent reason. They also have inexplicably created an awkward computer program (robot?) responsible for maintaining a lurid facade of human culture through insipid daily radio broadcasts to nobody in particular--perhaps to subconsciously placate the few remaining humans they have trapped in stasis for unanticipated future exploitation? The developers have sold themselves short by failing to highlight these key plot points in the game's summary.\n\nI challenge anybody to observe the complete lack of pedestrians, the fact that none of the cars have drivers, and the radio announcer's bizarre sense of humor and delivery style, and come to any other conclusion about this game's backstory. Driving through this environment is subtly unnerving after a while, evoking a sensation similar to observing desiccated corpses on Miranda and trying to figure out what the hell happened here. 11/10, would play again.

reviewText: This is a pretty good car and motorcycle driving game that allows you total freedom to go wherever you want in the huge world of Paradise City. And you don't have to do the challenges until you want to (completing challenges unlocks more vehicles). Although the game does have some MAJOR flaws (some of which are just plain stupid and should have been changed/fixed). There is no speedometer at all. You can't listen to your own music files on your computer while playing the game unless you run your own media player in the background. If you're playing online and your framerate gets too low, the game automatically kicks you from the server (even if it's your own server that you're hosting). Yes, you can get kicked from your own server if your framerate gets too low. There is no in game text chatting. You have to use a mic to communicate with other players on a server. As you upgrade your license, the races get MUCH harder because the AI will very often put cars right in front of you which are almost guaranteed to make you crash over and over. If you go too fast, you are very likely to crash over and over. If you take your time, it can be hard to get to first place. So it's a pretty good game, but with some MAJOR flaws. This game has given me an idea as to why EA was voted the world's worst video game company multiple times. Because of this game's MAJOR flaws, I don't recommend it

reviewText:
The classic arcade drifting and turbo-boosting racing that made the Burnout series famous, except now in a totally wide open city sandbox playground. The city itself feels like one of those Hot Wheels playsets instead of a grid of interlocking streets with railings everywhere. Expect to be driving across rooftops, through airfields and off of dams and seeing some of the best car deforming crashes that are only rivaled by a few other racers. The car selection is especially varied, even for a Burnout game, forget dodging traffic when your bigass 4x4 just knocks them away. The soundtrack, predictably, is both lame, and catchy. Classic Burnout right there.

+Classic Burnout IN A SANDBOX
+Totally drivable city/countryside
+Diverse car selection
+Trademark crashing physics with a new Driveway system
-DJ Atomica
-Google has perfected Driverless cars
-Does not include The Island

Note: Download the Paradise Vanity pack to have access to the DLC content that was never released on PC, such as Big Surf Island, as well as other bonus features.

reviewText:
One of the best arcade style racing games of this generation. Much better than Need for Speed.

Burnout Paradise takes from previous Burnout titles the insane speed, and emphasis on wreck or be wrecked style of racing that has been cloned now in several other arcade racing titles. But nobody can do it better than Burnout. What Paradise adds over previous Burnout titles is an open world hub to race around in be it on 4 wheels, or now on 2 wheels with the addition of motorcycles. Open world gameplay adds a new spin on progression, as expected, and also opens up point to point races in a whole new way. No more barriers. The other cars go left? You go right. Right to the finish line. Or right into a brick wall.

Granted, this is still an EA title, so there are some annoyances. Lack of DLC over on the steam version being one. Also, poor update support. And on top of that, EA's signature annoying announcer, unskippable cutscenes, and a soundtrack that can not make it's mind up. Guns N Roses, Faith No More, Soundgarden? Nice! Avril Lavigne.....WHAT? Okay. Nitpicking the last few parts. But anyway, the ultimate box is quite nice for the price! I just wish I could buy DLC from steam.
