reviewText:
I was a major fan of Burnout, especially Burnout revenge (this game's predecessor). But this game completely changed the Burnout formula - it's NOTHING like the previous titles.

The first problem - and the biggest by far - is the extremely poor menus. How many racing games since 1996 have lacked a 'restart' feature? If there's no way you're going to win the race, there's no way to stop. Then, when you do finish, you need to manually drive back to the event's starting point if you want another chance. Why can't you restart the event like every other Burnout title - or indeed, every other racing game?

In fact, EVERYTHING is done by manually driving to it. Want to use another car? Drive to the junkyard. Want to race? Drive to the starting line. I understand the upsides to this feature - driving through a gas station fills your boost meter, and  driving through a repair center fixes your car, and this awesome feature can completely turn a race around. But why do you need to do this when you're NOT racing? And why do you need to repair your car BETWEEN events - it's just tedious busywork. In fact, you'll spend more time with this busywork than actually racing. In every race, marked man, and time trial event, the finish line is always one of 9 locations on the edge of the map. Since all the starting locations are at intersections and most of the intersections are near the center of the map, you'll always finish an event as far away as possible from starting your next event.

This could all be forgiven if the actual gameplay was fun. The problem with the gameplay is two-fold. First - your AI opponents are far too easy for most of the game. You'll finish every race event at least 10 seconds ahead. The Destruction Derby event usually requires you to takedown 3 or 4 cars when you can easily takedown 15 (these events also force you to keep playing AFTER YOU ALREADY WON until the time runs out). Marked Man - the anti-destruction derby where your goal is to survive constant takedown attempts against you - has opponents that can barely turn and get lost easily.

Not that I can blame them - the player can get lost easily as well. You see, the whole idea of Paradise city is that there are no 'tracks', just a starting line and a finish line, and you decide your route yourself. Not a bad idea in concept, but it doesn't work in practice. The obvious problem is the player can and will make wrong turns - one wrong turn can cost you the race. The game tries to guide you... with street names. When you're racing through the city at 200 MPH, you can't tell which of those 5 turns you're about to pass is Hamilton Ave. Even worse, your AI opponents completely ignore this premise, they almost always all follow the same route.

There's a reason they stopped making Burnout after this.

reviewText:
I'm not really a fan of racing games... but Burnout is something that I really like and enjoy. Around the fictional setting of Paradise City cars are meant to be smashed, shortcuts and super jumps discovered, and multiple routes toward the same finish line exploited. Winning challenges nets you new rides and better licenses to take on more difficult challenges. The city itself isn't a metropolis teeming with life--you won't see pedestrians wandering around or anything like that--but there's plenty of traffic on the roads and shortcuts to discover as you freely drive around. While in the confines of your car you can pull up at stoplights to trigger events of different types, like stunt challenges, races, marked man (reach a finish line while other drivers try to smash you to bits) and road rage (destroy a set number of cars within a time limit) events, as well as timed runs. The soundtrack is really nice because it suits the atmosphere of the game. What could possibly be better than speeding down the highway through the thick traffic while being chased by 3 heavily armored vehicles and listening to some classic music. The game has a pretty big and nice collection of classic tracks that I enjoy most. Anyway, if you're not really into racing games, but you do want to play something like that - Burnout it is.



10/10

reviewText:
The classic arcade drifting and turbo-boosting racing that made the Burnout series famous, except now in a totally wide open city sandbox playground. The city itself feels like one of those Hot Wheels playsets instead of a grid of interlocking streets with railings everywhere. Expect to be driving across rooftops, through airfields and off of dams and seeing some of the best car deforming crashes that are only rivaled by a few other racers. The car selection is especially varied, even for a Burnout game, forget dodging traffic when your bigass 4x4 just knocks them away. The soundtrack, predictably, is both lame, and catchy. Classic Burnout right there.

+Classic Burnout IN A SANDBOX
+Totally drivable city/countryside
+Diverse car selection
+Trademark crashing physics with a new Driveway system
-DJ Atomica
-Google has perfected Driverless cars
-Does not include The Island

Note: Download the Paradise Vanity pack to have access to the DLC content that was never released on PC, such as Big Surf Island, as well as other bonus features.

reviewText:
I'm not really a fan of racing games... but Burnout is something that I really like and enjoy. Around the fictional setting of Paradise City cars are meant to be smashed, shortcuts and super jumps discovered, and multiple routes toward the same finish line exploited. Winning challenges nets you new rides and better licenses to take on more difficult challenges. The city itself isn't a metropolis teeming with life--you won't see pedestrians wandering around or anything like that--but there's plenty of traffic on the roads and shortcuts to discover as you freely drive around. While in the confines of your car you can pull up at stoplights to trigger events of different types, like stunt challenges, races, marked man (reach a finish line while other drivers try to smash you to bits) and road rage (destroy a set number of cars within a time limit) events, as well as timed runs. The soundtrack is really nice because it suits the atmosphere of the game. What could possibly be better than speeding down the highway through the thick traffic while being chased by 3 heavily armored vehicles and listening to some classic music. The game has a pretty big and nice collection of classic tracks that I enjoy most. Anyway, if you're not really into racing games, but you do want to play something like that - Burnout it is.



10/10

reviewText:
One of the best arcade style racing games of this generation. Much better than Need for Speed.

Burnout Paradise takes from previous Burnout titles the insane speed, and emphasis on wreck or be wrecked style of racing that has been cloned now in several other arcade racing titles. But nobody can do it better than Burnout. What Paradise adds over previous Burnout titles is an open world hub to race around in be it on 4 wheels, or now on 2 wheels with the addition of motorcycles. Open world gameplay adds a new spin on progression, as expected, and also opens up point to point races in a whole new way. No more barriers. The other cars go left? You go right. Right to the finish line. Or right into a brick wall.

Granted, this is still an EA title, so there are some annoyances. Lack of DLC over on the steam version being one. Also, poor update support. And on top of that, EA's signature annoying announcer, unskippable cutscenes, and a soundtrack that can not make it's mind up. Guns N Roses, Faith No More, Soundgarden? Nice! Avril Lavigne.....WHAT? Okay. Nitpicking the last few parts. But anyway, the ultimate box is quite nice for the price! I just wish I could buy DLC from steam.

reviewText:
Burnout has traditionally been a series of incredibly high-speed races where you race to the finish line, while destroying your opponents cars in a sweet, satisfying, firey spectacle.

Paradise does this, but it adds a few more game modes, and an open-world concept.

This game is an example of open-world done in the wrong way. Essentially, the driving around that you do in the open world is not particularly fun. There is not much to do, and you are only doing it to get to the next event. All of the Burnout appeal mentioned in the first sentence of this review is completely absent when driving around on the open world streets.

So, while the game still has the fun Burnout experience, it is watered down with tons and tons of filler.

6/10 Okay""

reviewText:
I have history with this game, I remember it like it was yesterday and by yesterday I mean 2009 on the PS3. When I picked this game up I thought great it's just going to be another burnout like always... but I was so wrong. This game to put it lightly was the start of a new era in the racing genre and at the time it may have just been a little ahead of it's time.

This has everything you would crave for in a burnout game, it has road rage, stunt runs, races, marked man and showtime just to name a few. The biggest and most amazing-est addition was free-roam and oh my god it is fun, with that comes a bunch of things like road rules, exploration, smashing fences and billboards, stunt jumps, hidden car parks, secret locations. Car unlocks are great you progress through and once you unlock one you go out into the open world and smash it down to collect it in your garage or you can collect some through collectibles and by completing a burning route race. Junkyards are your garages for cars, bikes etc there's also paint shops (gas stations). If your not the biggest fan of cars the ultimate box comes with bikes with there own set of races. It has online and there you can roam, race and explore with friends or strangers. Did I mention the soundtrack? OH THE SOUNDTRACK is something to admire because it's the kind of playlist you won't hear nowadays. The keyboard and mouse work fine fully rebind-able keys and the same goes for a controller straight out of the box. Navigation in this game is simple yet so good it doesn't hold your hand, you have to remember paths and sometimes rely on tail lights. The crash cams are still as good as they use to be if not better, with all the head on collisions and metal scrapping and crunching. The greatest thing about this game is the fact that the game revolves around what you progress through, there's no story just freedom.

I would love to say this game has nothing wrong with it I really really really do want to say it's perfect but it's not and why is that? Firstly the big issue is the false advertising since I've been around from the early days the ultimate box feels like a scam, I mean all you get is free DLC FREE" everything else you have to buy which would be fine if the store didn't shut down
date: if you want the awesome content you have to go through a bunch of loopholes. Secondly they left out content which are "Cop and Robbers" and "Big Surf Island" huge content missing from a near perfect game. Also a minor issue is the game doesn't have windowed mode so for all you lovers out there sorry but it just straight up isn't here.\n\nI would still say the game is worth buying because the single player is still fun and the community is some what still active
recommended: BUT if you do have the option to purchase a console copy go straight ahead because at least there you'll get a more updated version."

reviewText:
Having a free city to roll around in has been quite the staple in the Need for Speed series. Now it's Burnout's turn. Does causing automobile mayhem in a free roaming genre work well?

The graphics in the game can be pretty impressive if you have the computer setup that's powerful enough to run, say, any Crysis game. You'll start to wonder if it's even possible to walk the streets of Paradise City without freaking out over the passing traffic and catch a glimpse of the rowdy, wreckless cars smashing each other up. Beautiful scratches and traded paints between every crash and takedown marked on each car!

The library of music for the game is a mix of top past rock, metal and remix hits for shredding through the streets, along with some orchestral classics for when you need to wind down and soak in the view of the city. However, if you had to classify them separately, then there's not a lot for the soundtrack. And depending on how many times you wanted to re-launch the game, you'll start to wonder if Guns N' Roses' Paradise City" is worth having in your head for ages to come.

The controls leave a little to be desired

reviewText:
If you're looking for a classic Burnout game this is NOT it! My overall critique for those that don't want to read the whole Review is, Buy it on sale! The price, at date of review, of $19.99 CAD is too much for what this game is. There are better racing games for the price and I suggest you look at some of them first!

This is an Open World racing game with Burnout-like mechanics. Road Rage is still one of the funnest game types you can play, with Marked Man following a close second, but becomes progressively harder the more you do it. This wouldn't be a bad thing if it allowed you hit as hard or defend as well as the NPC cars. It goes from NPC cars wondering into walls, basically taking themselves down, to almost god-like AI that knows exactly when you plan to boost and/or ram and reacts to you. I fine with a challenge but this is a pathetic substitution for skill/balance.

Navigation in Paradise City is Hit or Miss, mostly miss as in oops I missed my turn! There's a compass/navigator that tells you when to turn but sometimes it doesn't activate until your on top of your turn. It's like driving with that one cousin that points out the side window as you pass your turn to say, that's the street we were supposed to turn onto!" which blows a substantial lead as you end up in a close 2nd. About as annoying/frustrating as it gets! Also
date: the races are bland and feel forced. You race because you have to in order to progress and don't get me started on the "Stunt Runs". They are the worst part of this game. There is so much they could have done but didn't do. It's sad really!\n\nI didn't play much of the online portion of the game
recommended: as I just don't care for that sort of thing
hoursPlayed: but from what I could see there was no Party Games which I remember fondly from previous Burnout games. The lack of game modes like Eliminator or Party Crash was a big let down and what is in game for online multiplayer is lack luster at best.\n\nOne annoying feature I found is the fact that your car looks half destroyed all the time. After you repair the car it looks nice for about 10 seconds and one bump later it looks like crap again. All this with no penalty outside of Marked Man or Road Rage. Your car never reaches critical and never blows up outside of those two game modes. Also

reviewText:
I bought this game a few minutes ago, and I regret my purchase. I'm having tons of issues, and I'm quite upset about this. If I cannot get the game working, I will ask Steam Support for a refund. ;(


EDIT (2 Days Later): I have gotten the game working. Bugs (mostly) aside, here's my ACTUAL review below.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For years, I'd heard little blurbs about this racing game called Burnout Paradise here and there. I'd seen it used at GameStop back when I was primarily a console gamer, but I never really paid it any attention. After seeing a popular YouTuber named NerdCubed do a video on it with his dad, I was sale hunting for this game.

The Steam Summer Sale came, and the game was $9.99 USD. A few of my close friends had the game, and loved it to death. I thought I'd pick it up, but it didn't just come with the game, nor just the DLC. I got an unwelcomed bonus - A NONFUNCTIONAL GAME. Multiple reinstalls, a lot of Googling, and hours of tinkering came before I got to properly experience this game. One problem after another bit me in the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥; the infamous DMV screen, crashing at the loading screen right when you start up the game... yada, yada. I got the game to open occasionally; sometimes, rarely, the game would launch flawlessly, and let me play just fine. The other 8 out of 10 times, it crashed. Until I fixed it, I'd only successfully launched the game three times in two days. I probably made 30+ attempts to launch the game. I tried every fix I could find on the internet, and none worked. I eventually thought to try Windows 95 Compatibility Mode again
date:
or so I thought. I thought I'd tried it already, but I must not have! After applying that fix (some people can only get it to work on certain compatibility modes; some XP SP3, some Vista only, some Win2000 only, etc.), the game launches flawlessly. Now, the only bug I get is the game freezes when I try to quit. Saves fine, just I have to manually kill the process on exit.

Steam claims I've played 8 hours of this game. I don't know how many hours of that (probably about 2) are just me trying to get it to launch properly. The game is phenomenal! The world is pretty large, with about 400 gates to smash (which lead you to backroads and alternate routes), and about 200 (I think, I'm not exactly sure) billboards to smash. Many of these billboards require you to do jumps on ramps to get to them, many of these jumps being at the end of the alternate routes that lie past those gates I told you about. I usually overlook elements like that in games, but in Paradise, I like going around and smashing them! Every intersection with a spotlight is a new race. You simply do a burnout (hold both triggers) to start one of these events; you have events where you must takedown other cars, races, events where you have to get somewhere without getting taken down, and more. There's plenty to do in Burnout Paradise!

There are over 75+ cars to choose from, as well as four bikes (which I think are more fun than the cars) added by the Burnout Bikes update included in The Ultimate Box. Allow me to note that TUB was a collection of all DLCs released up to that point; Criterion had no intention to keep making more expansions when they released TUB, but they did, The Burnout Store is down, so you can't buy the other DLCs if you don't go onto either Amazon or GreenManGaming and buy a code. The racing style is very arcadey, but you can also do barrel rolls and stuff when you do jumps, which feels very good and solid. On the cars (and cars ONLY, not bikes) you can boost your vehicle. You have different types of cars like Aggression (for takedowns and strength for when you crash) and Stunt (which are faster and more for doing stunts, but crash and are wrecked very easily). The driving in this game is great, and feels amazing.

The graphics in this game are pretty good, as well as the overall feel. My 650m cannot run it at maximum settings, but my buddy's dual Titans smoke it. It is a pretty good-looking game, especially when you crank it up. The visuals department is top-notch!

The soundtrack is amazing, although there's only one song I really pay attention to - Paradise City" by Guns 'n' Roses. That song alone makes the soundtrack AWESOME....!

Overall

reviewText:
I was an Original Burnout, and Burnout 2 player for a Long time. When take downs came into play that hampered the thrill of street racing, and pulled the focus off the racing.

This game has really good graphics, phyisics, a wonderful feeling of speed in game, addictive play, good varity of roads and conditions, the feel and response of every vehicle is different and requires you to learn each one.

This game pays awesome tribute to the look and feel of what made Brunout Great, the open world is fun to race non stop throughout, the selections of challenges is large, but this game has a few features that Really get in the way of My enjoyment.

So much time is wasted in Cinematic moments, at jumps, at crashes, at take downs, at race beginings, at race endings, at paint shops, at repair shops, at gas stations, each time taking control of Your car away from You. All the time this causes me car to crash, or go down the wrong street... Changing the frequency, or turning that off would have helped so much...
I can't change the zoom on the minimap to actually use it, and moving through all the menus just to get to a useable map took a long time because even menu screens have a cinimatic effect, choosing a car has a cinimatic effect, and nothing could be skipped.

Open world also meant no restart buttons if you failed an event, so you have to back track to the starting point by yourself, and this ate a Lot of time.

If you can handle a world where the car never stops, and cinimatics leave  you without control of your vehicle often, the rest of this game is awesome. I still hope to learn some patience with it, and I have yet to test online play so I'm hoping that may help.  I LOVE open world racing games, but this one may not be the one for me.

reviewText:
Back in the all too distant past at university a guy on my corridor had one of the burnout games which featured an amazingly fun looking mode where you had you cause as much damage as possible by crashing into an intersection and that is why I bought this game. Much to my disappointment the equivalent mode in this game just wasn't that great. You just start a crash on any stretch of road with limited degree of control and all the cars swerve towards you until you reach a required target. The older version was more like a puzzle to solve with a fixed arrangement of traffic.

That was only the start of the disappointment, the biggest problem is with the phrase â€œUltimate Boxâ€. When a game proclaims to be a superlative edition my expectation is that it is the base game combined with all the available DLC but no this is the base game with the free updates only. When you try and access the DLC it takes you to a store front that no longer works and they are not available on Steam either. There are apparently ways to buy the DLC but I didn't like the core game enough to want to investigate this option.

The actual game continued to disappoint me. The game has an open world environment however the actual races all end in a small number of locations making all the races seem unnecessarily similar. The races do not follow any fixed route but the navigation system is terrible, you have a compass that shows you the overall direction to the finish but the only clue about which road to take  is a little road sign that pops up too late to make the turn in the faster cars. There is also a mini map but looking at that is a sure fire way to crash into something so effectively you just have to learn the map. The game progression is too unfocused for me, you just complete an arbitrary number of races to unlock the next licence. Also there is no option to quit or restart and event you have to complete the event and then drive all the way back to the start point.

The other annoyance is all the collectables. I do love a nice set of collectable items in a game but this just has too many for it to work. There are 400 gates to smash through, there is no way you can collect all these while still having fun, you must just be driven by the desire for completion. You are bound to miss a few and then end up painstakingly going through a walktrhough revisiting all the locations till you find the ones you missed. And there is not just the gates there are jumps and best times on every road and biggest crashes on every road.

One of the items of DLC that did come with the ultimate box was the multiplayer party DLC which was again (I keep coming back to this word) disappointing. It had no split screen options, the events are repetitive and the load times are just that bit too long so it starts getting aggravating as you are passing the controller between players.

All of these problems are a real shame as the core game engine is excellent with great driving, spectacular crashing, a decent range of cars, a good map and variety of events. And in the sale this cost less than the price of a bus ticket. Given all the annoyances in the game I can't bring myself to recommend this game.

reviewText:
I was an Original Burnout, and Burnout 2 player for a Long time. When take downs came into play that hampered the thrill of street racing, and pulled the focus off the racing.

This game has really good graphics, phyisics, a wonderful feeling of speed in game, addictive play, good varity of roads and conditions, the feel and response of every vehicle is different and requires you to learn each one.

This game pays awesome tribute to the look and feel of what made Brunout Great, the open world is fun to race non stop throughout, the selections of challenges is large, but this game has a few features that Really get in the way of My enjoyment.

So much time is wasted in Cinematic moments, at jumps, at crashes, at take downs, at race beginings, at race endings, at paint shops, at repair shops, at gas stations, each time taking control of Your car away from You. All the time this causes me car to crash, or go down the wrong street... Changing the frequency, or turning that off would have helped so much...
I can't change the zoom on the minimap to actually use it, and moving through all the menus just to get to a useable map took a long time because even menu screens have a cinimatic effect, choosing a car has a cinimatic effect, and nothing could be skipped.

Open world also meant no restart buttons if you failed an event, so you have to back track to the starting point by yourself, and this ate a Lot of time.

If you can handle a world where the car never stops, and cinimatics leave  you without control of your vehicle often, the rest of this game is awesome. I still hope to learn some patience with it, and I have yet to test online play so I'm hoping that may help.  I LOVE open world racing games, but this one may not be the one for me.

reviewText:
Here's how you do it. Go to the music settings and disable all the tedious modern music that EA insists on cramming in the game. Then enable the classical tracks that are also included for some reason. Then go drive like a madman and crash while listening to Ave Maria.

Paradise is a pretty good game, but it's main draw is that it supports a rather wide range of behaviour. In some ways it's a platform game. In others it's a racing game. In some it's a exploration game.

I could argue that it's some sort of post apocalyptic game where humans are dead and cars are now sentient. It's a bit eerie at times, to drive around in the barren world.
Slap on some Mozart though, and it's golden!

If you can snag it for cheap I recommend this game.

reviewText: It's a pretty decent racing game. You will play it and find little things that tick you off after a while and uninstall the game. Months to years later you will reinstall it not remembering what was so bad, then within seconds of playing it all comes back to you. The decent part about it is that the driving is very fun and very fluid, 2 qualities that make or break racing games. SO, what ticks me off you ask? The narator that wont shut the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up stating the obvious after you have been playing for hours and know everything already. The fact that you can just bearly scrape against an object and it goes into a slomo action cam as you reen off course in a metal ball of scrap signifying your loss of 1st place (this will happen every single race more than once). Don't get me wrong, going over 140mph is really fun and satisfying, but when your only 5 activity options include smashing billboards, racing, jumping off ramps, and finding shortcuts all for collection's sake you will get bored quickly. The driving and racing part of this game are flawless and make the game, the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ of everything else breaks the fun part.

reviewText: A fantastic fast paced arcade style action racer! Fast cars, crazy stunts, big crashes, Burnout Paradise has it all. Even now after it's aged a little it's still a fantastically fun game to play, great for a quick blast or in multiplayer. With lots of DLC available now it's really fleshed out the game. It's very playable with loads of stunt jumps to do, events to race and all kinds of stuff to keep you entertained.
